channel.title: Maclaurin Series?
channel.description:
Hey, just doing some quick review for calc and got stuck.
The Maclaurin series for the function [i]f[/i] is given by f(x) = ∑(2,∞) [((-1)^n)*((2x)^n)]/[n-1]. (Basically, series from n=2 to n=∞.)
(a) Find the interval of convergence for the Maclaurin series of [i]f[/i]. Justify your answer.
Ans: I used the ratio test:
lim n -> ∞ |(An+1) / (An) | < 1 if it converges.
.. steps, etc.
|2x| < 1
-0.5 < x < 0.5
Testing endpoints gives:
f(-0.5) diverges. f(0.5) converges.
Therefore:
[b]The interval of convergence for the series is: -0.5 < x ≤ 0.5 or (-0.5, 0.5][/b]
_________________________________________________
(b) <- Where I'm stuck.. Show that y = f(x) is a solution to the differential equation xy' - y = (4x^2)/(1+2x) for |x| < R, where R is the radius of convergence from part (a).
This is what I've attempted to do:
f(x) = [(2x)^2]/1 - [(2x)^3]/2 + [(2x)^4]/3 - [(2x)^5]/4 + . . . + [((-1)^n)*((2x)^n)]/[n-1] + . . .
f(x) = 4x^2 - 4x^3 + (16/3)x^4 - 8x^5 + . . . + [((-1)^n)*((2x)^n)]/[n-1] + . . .
f'(x) = 8x - 12x^2 + (64/3)x^3 - 40x^4 + . . . + [((-1)^n)*2n((2x)^(n-1))]/[n-1] + . . .
xy' = xf'(x) = 8x^2 - 12x^3 + (64/3)x^4 - 40x^5 + . . . + [((-1)^n)*2nx((2x)^(n-1))]/[n-1] + . . .
xy' -y = xf'(x) - f(x) = 4x^2 - 8x^3 + 16x^4 - 32x^5 + . . . + [u]{[((-1)^n)*2nx((2x)^(n-1))]/[n-1]} - {[((-1)^n)*((2x)^n)]/[n-1]}[/u] + . . .
I can't seem to figure out how to evaluate that and simplify it. I don't really know if my work is correct thus far either, so checking it for me would be great!
Thanks in advance!
I know how to do the rest of the problem after I simplify the underlined blob.
- Jason
PS: Don't Google this if you don't know anything about this topic or calculus in general, since it will be a waste of time. Thanks..
